message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH stands for antidiuretic hormone, which is also known as arginine vasopressin. Increased levels of ADH are associated with small cell lung carcinoma, which presents as sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. The other options do not fit the histologic appearance of small cell lung carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH stands for antidiuretic hormone, which is sometimes produced by small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC). SCLC is known for its small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. Therefore, the most likely histologic appearance of the mass in this scenario is sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH (antidiuretic hormone) is a marker for small cell lung carcinoma, which presents as sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. None of the other options correspond to this histologic appearance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH (antidiuretic hormone) is commonly produced by small cell carcinoma of the lung, which presents as sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. None of the other answer options match this histologic appearance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH, or antidiuretic hormone, is commonly released by small cell lung carcinoma, which is characterized by sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. Tall columnar cells describe adenocarcinoma, layered squamous cells describe squamous cell carcinoma, and pleomorphic giant cells describe large cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH (antidiuretic hormone) is associated with small cell lung carcinoma, which presents with sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. The other options are associated with other types of lung cancer: (A) adenocarcinoma, (C) squamous cell carcinoma, and (D) large cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated ADH levels suggest a possible small cell carcinoma of the lung, which is characterized by sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. The other options do not match the histologic appearance of small cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH (antidiuretic hormone) is a peptide hormone produced by the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior pituitary gland. It increases water reabsorption in the kidneys, and when increased, usually signals small cell carcinoma of the lung, which presents as sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH stands for antidiuretic hormone, which is produced by small cell lung cancer. Therefore, the histologic appearance of the mass is sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. Options (A), (C), and (D) are not commonly associated with lung cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ADH (Antidiuretic hormone) is secreted by small cell carcinoma of the lung, which is characterized by sheets of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. None of the other options fit this description.
